Culinary Profile & Uses
1. Flavour and Form

It offers a mild, sweet, and subtly earthy flavour, often compared to a cross between spinach and watercress. Its magic lies in its texture: the hollow stems (petioles) remain incredibly crisp and succulent when cooked, while the leaves wilt into tenderness. This cultivar produces an abundance of tender stems with minimal fibre.

2. The Stir-Fry Sovereign

This green is the star of the wok, but its uses are wonderfully diverse.

  • The Classic Stir-Fry: The most famous preparation is Pad Pak Bung Fai Daeng (flash-fried water spinach with chili and garlic). Its hollow stems literally “drink” up the savoury sauce, creating an unforgettable texture and flavour in every bite.
  • Soups & Curries: Adds a refreshing, crisp element to brothy soups like Sinigang and coconut-based curries, where it softens slightly but retains a pleasant bite.
  • Fresh & Blanched: Young leaves and stems can be used fresh in salads or quickly blanched and dressed with sesame oil and soy for a simple, elegant side dish.
3. The Harvest and Yield

The plant grows vigorously, producing long, vining stems. Harvesting is a ‘cut-and-come-again’ process; snipping the main stem -2 inches from the base encourages the growth of multiple new side shoots. A single HydraPad™ provides a continuous yield of 150–200g of prime stems and leaves per week.
